channel.title: Linux Advice
channel.description:
Ok, I recently built my own computer, With Kubuntu 9.04 32-bit, KDE 4. And I was just wondering if anyone had any advice. Right now I have:
Intel Q9550 CPU(64-bit compatible) 4 Gigs Ram ATI Radeon HD 4890
O'm really just wondering what I should do to make the most out of my system.

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

I fixed it. I forgo that my dad set the router to not broadcast it’s ssid, sop i had to do connect to hidden network.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

we need error messages or something, we can’t see your pc ¬_¬

try dmesg | tail immediately after attempting to connect, if nothing comes up on screen

Read full topic

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

I Fixed it. The reason it didn’t show up before was because it didn’t have a network connection. BUt I’m still having issues getting the Wireless card working.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

Been awhile since I used Kubuntu but isnt there like a sources.list file or something that contains all the databases for your package manager?

Read full topic

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Ok, thanks.

Edit: Also, Since my router is hidden/Not broadcasting(So i can’t do Scan on the wireless connection manager), would I need to put in the MAC ID? I’ve put in the NEtwork name and pass correctly, but it still won’t let me connect.

for some reason, sudo apt-get is not finding any packages. Right now I’m directly connected to my internet, and whenever i try to do sudo apt-get install ndiswrapper-common, or wine, it says that it can’t find the package. when I do lspci -n, it shows that my wireless card is installed.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Don’t use that installer at all

As far as I can tell, that card uses the rt2500 chipset, which should mean it works automatically on Kubuntu - if it dosen’t, have a bit of a Google for “EDIMAX EW-7128G Ubuntu” or “rt2500 Ubuntu” to see which packages you need to install. That disc will probably be useless to you.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

The reason I need Wine, is because my Wireless adapter, here came with an installation disc, that contains the linux drivers, well, a directory that says linux drivers, but the installer is an exe.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

wine won’t do anything for you when it comes to wireless cards, you may have meant ndiswrapper instead which allows you to use windows wireless drivers under linux.

64-bit linux would be nice, I can’t tell you it will give you any noticeable performance increase though unless you are running a web server and database or something like that. But really now that there are 64-bit flash and java plugins there are really no reasons left not to use it.

If you want to ‘get the most’ out of your machine, install some awesome linux games. Doom 3, Quake 4, Enemy Territory: Quake Wars, just to name a few.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

Mopman:

uh… why would you need wine for your wireless adapter?

im assuming because it has some bullshit useless gui (that ‘replaces’ the default windows one).

bro, that probably wont work anyway. l2wireless

Read full topic

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

uh… why would you need wine for your wireless adapter?

Read full topic

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

I was planning on installing 64 bit. I Just need to install wine, so that I can start my wireless adapter working. Should I use KDE 3.5 instead of 4?

Read full topic

item.title: Linux Advice
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

zyle1992:

O’m really just wondering what I should do to make the most out of my system.

Install 64 bits linux.

Read full topic
